intro: Lepidium propinquum, commonly known as the common peppergrass, is an annual herbaceous plant native to North America. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many edible and economically important plants. The plant has small, white or yellowish flowers that bloom in early spring, and its leaves are alternate, simple, and often covered in fine hairs. Lepidium propinquum typically grows in disturbed soils, such as roadsides and fields, and can reach heights of up to 30 centimeters. It is characterized by its cylindrical, segmented fruits that are often referred to as siliques.
